message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is pregnant, and Tdap and influenza vaccines are recommended for pregnant women to protect against pertussis and flu. Varicella vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy. Hepatitis B and MMR are not recommended during pregnancy unless there is a specific indication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is in her 28th week of pregnancy, and Tdap and influenza vaccines are recommended during pregnancy to prevent pertussis and flu. The other vaccine options are not indicated for routine administration during pregnancy. Hepatitis B vaccine is usually given to newborns, and MMR vaccine is given postpartum. The patient's blood group is B negative, so she may require Rh immunoglobulin administration in case of Rh incompatibility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Tdap and influenza vaccines are most appropriate during pregnancy to protect the mother and the newborn from respiratory infections and pertussis. Varicella and MMR vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy, and hepatitis B vaccine is usually given before pregnancy or after delivery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is pregnant and should receive vaccines that are safe for pregnancy. Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) is recommended during each pregnancy to protect newborns from pertussis. Influenza vaccine is also recommended for pregnant women to reduce the risk of influenza-related complications. Varicella and MMR vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy, and Hepatitis B vaccine is not necessary unless the patient is at high risk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient's gestation, Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis) and influenza vaccines are most appropriate at this time. Varicella and MMR vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy, and Hepatitis B vaccine is only given if the patient is at high risk or requested by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At 28 weeks of gestation, the patient should receive Tdap (Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis) vaccine to protect the newborn from pertussis after delivery. Influenza vaccine is also recommended for pregnant women to protect both the mother and baby from the flu. Varicella vaccine should be given before pregnancy if the woman is not immune, and Hepatitis B vaccine is recommended for high-risk individuals, such as healthcare workers and those with multiple partners. MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella) vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is pregnant, so the most appropriate vaccines are those that are safe for pregnant women and protect both the mother and the fetus. Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) and influenza vaccines are safe for pregnant women and highly recommended by the CDC. The other options are either not recommended or contraindicated during pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is pregnant and needs vaccination to protect herself and her unborn child. Tdap and influenza are recommended during pregnancy to protect against pertussis and influenza. Varicella vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy. Hepatitis B and MMR are not necessary at this time.

We refer to the CDC website on vaccination for help. Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis) vaccine is recommended during each pregnancy, preferably between 27 and 36 weeks of gestation, regardless of previous vaccination. Influenza vaccine is recommended during any trimester of pregnancy to protect both the mother and the fetus. Varicella vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy as it is a live vaccine and MMR vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy. Hepatitis B vaccine may be considered based on the patient's risk factors, but it is not routinely recommended during pregnancy unless the patient is already at high risk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Tdap vaccine is recommended during every pregnancy to protect the newborn from pertussis. Influenza vaccine is also recommended during pregnancy to protect the mother and infant from flu-related complications. Varicella vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy, and Hepatitis B and MMR vaccines are not typically given during pregnancy. The patient's blood group being B negative is not relevant to the vaccination decision.
